'Longifolene' is the common (or trivial) chemical name of a naturally occurring,
oily liquid hydrocarbon found primarily in the high-boiling fraction of certain
pine resins. The name is derived from that of a pine species from which the
compound was isolated, Naffa, P.; Ourisson, G. Bulletin de la SociÃ©tÃ©
chimique de France, '1954', 1410. Pinus longifolia (obsolete name for
[[Pinus roxburghii]] Sarg.) Simonsen, J. L. J. Chem. Soc. '1920', 117,
570.

Chemically, longifolene is a tricyclic sesquiterpene. This molecule is chiral,
and the enantiomer commonly found in pines and other higher plants exhibits a
positive optical rotation of +42.73Â°. The other enantiomer (optical rotation
â42.73Â°) is found in small amounts in certain fungi and liverworts.

Longifolene is used in organic synthesis for the preparation of
dilongifolylborane, Jadhav, P. K.; Brown, H. C. [[J. Org. Chem.]] '1981',
46, 2988. a chiral hydroborating agent.

Longifolene is also one of two most abundant aroma constituents of lapsang
souchong tea, because the tea is smoked over pine
fires. [http://d.wanfangdata.com.cn/NSTLQK_NSTL_QK10615205.aspx Shan-Shan
Yaoï¼ Wen-Fei Guoï¼ YI Luï¼ Yuan-Xun Jiang, "Flavor Characteristics of Lapsang
Souchong and Smoked Lapsang Souchong,a Special Chinese Black Tea with Pine
Smoking Process", Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Vol. 53, No.22,
(2005)]
